name: wrangler
content:
wrangler noun [C]
(CARES FOR ANIMALS)
Add to word list
Add to word list
mainly US someone who controls and looks after animals, especially horses or cows on a ranch (= a large farm in North or South America): I'm working as a horse wrangler - I've been riding all my life. The kids can watch actual wranglers at work at a ranch just south of the campground. He worked as a tourist guide and crocodile wrangler.
More examplesFewer examplesTo help deal with the problem of the wild horses, wranglers will be rounding up more than 10,000 in the area this year.He talked about the dangers of his work as a snake wrangler.The buffalo, with constant urging from the wranglers, made steady progress toward the corrals.

wrangler noun [C]
(CONTROLS STH)
a person who deals with or controls something or someone, often when this is difficult: She's now his co-producer and general wrangler on the film set. His key skill is as an information wrangler.
More examplesFewer examplesWorking with so many babies on the movie, she said she felt more like a child wrangler than an actress.A whip in parliament is a kind of vote wrangler.A bike wrangler collects and returns bicycles that have been taken outside the boundary of the park.

wrangler noun [C]
(STUDENT)
at the University of Cambridge, a student of mathematics who has passed their final examinations with first class honours (= the highest possible level): He had a distinguished undergraduate career, being a Wrangler in Part II of the Mathematical Tripos. The student attaining the highest marks was called the senior wrangler.
More examplesFewer examplesIn 1890, Sylvia Fawcett obtained the top score in the Cambridge Mathematical Tripos, but was not given the title of senior wrangler, as at that time only men were eligible. Watson, second wrangler of 1759, later delivered lectures upon chemistry.
